captions.text: Second Wind
[Intro Music]

&quot;Hey, we&#39;ve made a new Persona g- OW! 
Why&#39;d you slam the door in my face?&quot; Atlus,

I told you last time, you and Persona aren&#39;t 
welcome here again until you&#39;ve got an actual

mainline instalment for me. That means no 
spinoffs with experimental combat mechanics,

no pachinko machines and definitely - let me 
take a moment to pick the right swear word to

emphasise this - no fanny batter fried dancing 
sims. &quot;Ah, but we do have an actual mainline

instalment this time!&quot; Do you really, Atlus? An 
all new full on hybrid JRPG dungeon crawler high

school life sim with day by day scheduling, 
battles for the soul of humanity and lots of

getting punched out for accidentally perving on 
the waifus in the bath? &quot;Yes, it&#39;s all of that,

and what&#39;s more, it&#39;s got a number on the 
end that isn&#39;t 5 and is a multiple of 3!&quot;

Holy shit! It&#39;s finally happened! Come 
right in, Atlus! &quot;Thank you, Yahtzee! Now,

please enjoy this remake of Persona 3 HA HA 
HA HA HA&quot; GAH ATLUS YOU PACKET OF KELLOGG&#39;S

JIZZ FLAKES! Tricked again. Oh well, shouldn&#39;t 
complain. Persona 5 and 4 are the two enormous

soapy tits on the chest of my personal ideal JRPG 
waifu but I&#39;ve never taken the time to try 3.

Because having played 4 and 5 and concluding 
that 4 was basically just 5 before it had

finished baking in the oven, the impression 
I had of 3 was that it was basically that

again but before it&#39;d so much as greased 
the cake tin, and I wasn&#39;t missing out on

any mindblowingly different experience - high 
school, metaphysical dungeons, perv on waifus,

blah blah blah, the precise details change but the 
same beats are hit, and I&#39;m not talking about the

immediate consequence of waifu perving. Even 
the central cast of characters draws from the

same bag of archetypes as always - the slacker 
idiot best friend who inevitably takes the lead

in perving operations, the serious boy, the posh 
girl, the smart girl, the... girl, girl. But in 4

and 5 the central peeps were cast with a bolder 
emphasis and more distinct personality quirks,

3&#39;s after school monster assassination club feel 
a trifle underbaked by comparison. &quot;Scoff scoff,&quot;

cry the Persona purists, &quot;Clearly he didn&#39;t 
play far enough to unlock the ten year old,

the dog or the mechanical sex doll 
party members.&quot; I did, actually,

and fun though those ideas are it does point to 
a game struggling to pin down a consistent tone.

And none of them are introduced with what I&#39;d 
consider the necessary degree of ceremony. Your

party&#39;s just like &quot;Oh okay, a sentient robot 
waifu, that&#39;s a perfectly acceptable thing

to see in a contemporary setting, welcome 
to the team, please add your name to the

perving roster.&quot; Persona 3 feels like a plot 
where all the important moments of discovery

happened offscreen while you were pissing about 
amusing small children in parks and eating at the

restaurant that makes your face greasy. In 4 and 
5 we discover the other world and our ability to

fight shadows with our Persona powers alongside 
the protagonist through mysterious intrigues

and twists of fate. Meanwhile 3&#39;s protagonist - 
about whom we know fuck all except they&#39;ve just

transferred to a new city and wherever they 
lived before apparently had prohibitively

expensive hairdressers - shows up to his new digs 
and some dude&#39;s there saying &quot;Hi! We fight Shadows

with our Personas and we want you to as well. 
Here&#39;s a starter kit of waifus who are already

Persona awakened. Oh and that dickhead friend of 
yours from school just Persona awakened too so

he&#39;s coming along. It happened just there, off 
screen. Shame you missed it, actually, it was

really dramatic and interesting to watch. Anyway, 
here&#39;s a gun, shoot yourself in the fucking face.&quot;

Maybe there&#39;s something to be said for setting the 
scene quickly so you can get to the interesting

stuff faster, but for that to work, something 
interesting has to happen. And Persona 3&#39;s plot

doesn&#39;t start getting interesting until you&#39;re 
about four feet deep into it and tickling the

back of its tonsils. I looked up the plot summary 
on Wikipedia, it&#39;s about five paragraphs long and

the first paragraph covers the first thirty-odd 
hours of gameplay. Go to school, befriend twats,

go to infinite tower of samey dungeons, come 
home, repeat for the approximate length of a

modestly-sized DVD box set and then maybe we&#39;ll 
unlock the fucking dog. Still, the Persona

experience is enough of a comfort zone for me 
now that I wasn&#39;t hating it. I was content to go

through the motions of progressing in the dungeon 
and rebuilding the usual Persona collection,

acknowledging each familiar face like it was 
my school reunion. Hi, Pixie. How&#39;s it going,

Narcissus. What up, Mara, still looking 
hauntingly like a bellend I see. Word on

the street is that the combat has been rehashed 
to be more Persona 5-y. The flashy interface,

the spectacular all-out attacks, the 
baton passing, which might go some way

to explaining why combat gets really fucking 
piss-easy in the back half of the game when

you&#39;ve got nine hundred superpowers to 
call on, but that&#39;s as much as I expect.

I notice we didn&#39;t include the way Persona 5 
had you fight and recruit Personas directly,

rather than have you fight a suite of gribbly 
monsters in order to have a chance of randomly

unlocking Personas from another, entirely separate 
suite of gribbly monsters. Always struck me as odd

the way it apparently took 5 games to notice 
the obvious way they could&#39;ve cut the workload

in half. But that aside, this brings us back 
to Persona 3&#39;s aforementioned problem with

consistent tone and theming, embodied by the dog, 
the ten year old and the robot waifu, the father,

the son and the holy ghost. The exciting energy 
of Persona 5 style battles and menus feels at

odds with the slightly morose tone of Persona 
3&#39;s original elements. The night time coffins,

our very depressed hairdo, oh and lest we forget, 
the fact that we summon our Personas by pulling

a gun and popping ourselves in the bonce. Every 
now and again I&#39;d wake from a repetitive dungeon

induced trance and reflect on how weird it would 
seem out of context, when the funky fight music

kicks in and everything bops along to it for a few 
moments before our dude casually but determinedly

beans himself in the skull. It&#39;s like an extremely 
ill-advised premise for a Saturday morning

cartoon. &quot;Okay gang, let&#39;s summon Captain Planet 
by all putting our heads in this magic noose.&quot;

I&#39;m just pulling your plonker, Persona 3 
Reload, part of me likes that you&#39;re a little

bit scatterbrained, if that&#39;s not an unfortunate 
choice of words, and yet, to anyone else who got

into the series from the later games, I still 
can&#39;t say you&#39;d miss much by skipping this one.

Whatever sparkly tinsel has been draped around it 
can&#39;t disguise the underbaked bits. It takes more

than new wallpaper every ten levels to make samey 
dungeon crawling not samey. There&#39;s only three

social stats and you&#39;ll probably max them out 
by the halfway point so you&#39;ll have nothing to

do all day but go through the somewhat uninspired 
array of social links, listening to boring randos

whine about their dead mums and their hurty legs. 
I nitpick now, as I said I always enjoy Persona&#39;s

gameplay model and it was hitting that G-spot, 
but I suppose intellectually I&#39;m still against

remaking old games to be up to date with the 
recent instalments, much as I was with RE4, &#39;cos

it&#39;s erasing history for the sake of homogeneity. 
There&#39;s a unique value to watching the process by

which a concept finds its groove. It&#39;s like 
the beauty of seeing a tree grow from a seed,

or a blooming flower of girlhood expand to fill 
out her training bra, or a vibrant purple bruise

slowly spreading out from your eye socket after 
the blooming flower of girlhood&#39;s dad shows up.
